--- Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
> I think Derek's point was that the NEAT method of
> historical markings,
> speciation, and starting with a minimal genome can
> in principle be
> applied to any encoding.  It's true that the
> encoding that I used in
> my papers and software is direct, but (Derek can
> correctly me if I'm
> wrong) I think Derek is anticipating in the future
> being able to
> change the encoding without having to write an
> entirely new system, 
> thereby eventually getting indirect versions of
> NEAT.

Yes...that's exactly right.  It may be the case that
in a variation of NEAT (like Joseph's) a single gene
encodes for a group of neurons and connections, or
encodes for a rule about how to construct a neural
network.  Or, as Ken pointed out, NEAT can
theoretically encode for phenotypes other than neural
networks.

Derek
